Existing Provision: Shares of a foreign company deriving substantial value from shares of an Indian company are deemed situated in India.
Problem or Issue in Existing Provision: Inconsistency between Explanation 5 and Section 47(vicc), causing exemption gaps for shares deriving value from Indian assets.
New Provision Suggestion: Amend Section 47(vicc) to cover all shares deriving value from Indian assets. Align with Explanation 5.
How Practically it will be Helpful: Avoids exemption gaps, ensuring consistency and fairness in demerger taxation.

Existing Provision: SEP applies broadly to all businesses, including traditional commerce. Attribution rules are unnotified.
Problem or Issue in Existing Provision: SEP intended for digital businesses but impacts traditional commerce. Attribution rules are missing.
New Provision Suggestion: Restrict SEP to digital commerce and defer tax obligations until attribution rules are notified.
How Practically it will be Helpful: Reduces compliance burden for non-digital businesses and provides clarity for tax attribution.

Existing Provision: Tax exemption only for mergers where the amalgamated company is Indian.
Problem or Issue in Existing Provision: Outbound mergers are excluded, creating tax liability and compliance burdens.
New Provision Suggestion: Extend tax exemptions to outbound mergers and relax FEMA compliance requirements.
How Practically it will be Helpful: Encourages cross-border mergers and aligns tax provisions with FEMA and Companies Act.

Problem or Issue in Existing Provision: India's narrower range misaligns with global practices, increasing compliance costs.
How Practically it will be Helpful: Reduces disputes and aligns Indian practices with global norms, simplifying compliance.

Existing Provision: Threshold for secondary adjustment is ₹1 crore, with no provision for reversing advances.
Problem or Issue in Existing Provision: Deemed advances create tax burdens without mechanisms for reversal when relationships cease.
New Provision Suggestion: Increase threshold to ₹2 crore and provide mechanisms for advance reversal.
How Practically it will be Helpful: Eliminates unnecessary tax burdens and facilitates business closures or changes.

Section: Section 94A & Section 206AA - Withholding Tax in NJA
Existing Provision: Withholding tax @30% applies in NJA, conflicting with Section 206AA (@20% for no PAN).
Problem or Issue in Existing Provision: Ambiguity over which provision (Section 94A or 206AA) prevails.
How Practically it will be Helpful: Reduces litigation and provides clarity on applicable withholding tax rates.

Existing Provision: Interest limitation applies to all interest, including AE-backed third-party loans.
Problem or Issue in Existing Provision: AE-backed loans attract disallowance, impacting infrastructure financing.
New Provision Suggestion: Exclude third-party loans and AE-backed guarantees from disallowance.
How Practically it will be Helpful: Encourages infrastructure investments by lowering financing costs.

Existing Provision: GAAR applies to arrangements with a tax benefit exceeding ₹3 crore.
Problem or Issue in Existing Provision: Low threshold of ₹3 crore; ambiguity in defining 'tax benefit' for GAAR.
New Provision Suggestion: Raise the threshold to ₹10 crore and define 'tax benefit' based on actual tax impact.
How Practically it will be Helpful: Focuses anti-avoidance efforts on high-value cases and reduces compliance ambiguity.

Existing Provision: Excess interest beyond approved rates may be taxed at 20%.
Problem or Issue in Existing Provision: Ambiguity may lead to higher TDS on excess interest.
New Provision Suggestion: Reword Section 194LC to avoid ambiguity on excess interest taxation.
How Practically it will be Helpful: Avoids unnecessary litigation and ensures clarity for taxpayers and companies.

Existing Provision: No time limit for AO decisions; penalties apply to non-taxable transactions.
Problem or Issue in Existing Provision: Undue delays and high penalties for non-taxable transactions.
New Provision Suggestion: Introduce a 30-day timeline for AO decisions and reduce penalties for non-taxable cases.
How Practically it will be Helpful: Streamlines processes, reducing delays and unnecessary penalties.

Section: Section 197 & Section 195 - TAN Requirement for Property Sales
Existing Provision: TAN is mandatory for one-time property transactions by resident buyers.
Problem or Issue in Existing Provision: Cumbersome registration and compliance process for resident buyers.
New Provision Suggestion: Allow CA-certified reports for lower TDS and exempt one-time property buyers from TAN requirements.
How Practically it will be Helpful: Simplifies compliance for resident buyers and avoids delays in property transactions.

Section: TCS on International Credit Card Payments
Existing Provision: No mechanism to track foreign currency credit card transactions.
Problem or Issue in Existing Provision: Credit card payments are not systematically tracked for taxation.
New Provision Suggestion: Introduce TCS provisions for credit card payments to capture transactions.
How Practically it will be Helpful: Tracks foreign payments systematically, improving tax collection.

Section: Section 204 - Definition of Person Responsible for Paying
Existing Provision: Definition of 'person responsible for paying' includes irrelevant references to Section 285.
Problem or Issue in Existing Provision: Section 204 references irrelevant sections and lacks clarity on collection responsibility.
New Provision Suggestion: Remove references to Section 285 and define 'person responsible for collecting.'
How Practically it will be Helpful: Improves clarity and ensures accurate responsibility assignments.

Existing Provision: Interest paid to third parties under AE guarantees triggers disallowance.
Problem or Issue in Existing Provision: Third-party interest is incorrectly included for disallowance.
New Provision Suggestion: Clarify that only AE interest is subject to disallowance; exempt Indian banks.
How Practically it will be Helpful: Encourages investments by reducing unnecessary disallowances.

Existing Provision: Interest income from secondary adjustments is not explicitly included in Section 2(24).
Problem or Issue in Existing Provision: No explicit inclusion of interest income from secondary adjustments as taxable.
New Provision Suggestion: Include interest income from secondary adjustments under Section 2(24).
How Practically it will be Helpful: Ensures clarity in taxable income, reducing litigation risks.
